Legal_Issue: Whether Pharmascience is prohibited from marketing its version of Urso® due to patent infringement
Procedural_Stage: Federal Court proceeding under the Patented Medicine (Notice of Compliance) Regulations
Evidence_Assessment: Analysis of prior publications, expert testimonies, and patent claims
Decision_Outcome: Patent is invalid; Pharmascience allowed to market its version
Burden_of_Proof: On Pharmascience to show patent invalidity
Credibility_Factor: Expert testimonies evaluated by the court
Legal_Rule: A patent is invalid if the invention was previously known or obvious; methods of medical treatment are not patentable
Standard_of_Review: Statutory interpretation and factual assessment under patent law
Procedural_Issue: Compliance with Notice of Compliance Regulations
Grounds_for_Claim: Prior knowledge of dosage range and unpatentable method of medical treatment
Outcome_on_Merits: Axcan’s application dismissed; no prohibition order issued
Review_Standard: Statutory review under the Patented Medicine (Notice of Compliance) Regulations
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Court followed proper procedures in evaluating evidence and arguments
Key_Evidence_Considered: Prior publications, expert testimony, patent claims
Legal_Framework: Patent Act, Patented Medicine (Notice of Compliance) Regulations
Applicant_Challenge: Axcan sought to prevent Pharmascience from marketing generic Ursodiol
Defendant_Response: Patent is invalid due to prior art and non-patentable subject matter
Outcome: Pharmascience permitted to market its version of Ursodiol
Remedy_Sought: Pre-market injunction based on patent validity
Legal_Provision: Section 41 of the Patent Act, PM(NOC) Regulations
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Invalidity due to prior art and non-statutory subject matter
